awd_titl_txt: EARS: Collaborative Research: Real-time Control of Dense, Mobile, Millimeter Wave Networks Using a Programmable Architecture
awd_abstract_narration:
The demand for wireless broadband is growing across the world. Access to high-rate wireless communication is becoming critical to the operation of any modern society. The increasing demand for spectrum requires novel solutions, capable of addressing the high-density and high-mobility expected of future wireless services. This project addresses the global need for ubiquitous wireless broadband by enabling new frequencies, specifically, the millimeter wave bands to be used in future networks. A novel agile architecture capable of supporting adaptation to varying network conditions will be developed in this project to enable efficient and seamless network operation in highly-dynamic environments characterized by high density and mobility of wireless devices. This architecture could provide low-cost broadband access nationwide by enabling the widespread use of millimeter wave networks without expensive infrastructure. The knowledge developed in this project will be integrated into course offerings and undergraduate education. All educational materials resulting from the proposed work will be widely shared with other universities.
 
This proposal explores the potential offered by millimeter wave bands as a solution to the increasing traffic demand (network density) and increasing mobility of wireless services. To enable a network-level adaptation, the proposed work will use the tools of software-defined networking (SDN). An SDN architecture allows controllers to run applications, interface with database and cloud-based servers, and adapt the radios to changing channel conditions. The level of flexibility and adaptability required for millimeter wave networks make SDN a natural fit. This work addresses the theoretical and experimental issues that are impeding the deployment of millimeter wave wireless broadband systems. Specifically, this project will focus on the interplay between network-level optimization and physical layer communication, channel sounding, and control. The optimization framework is based on programmability, which will be enabled by the SDN framework developed in the project. The SDN will interface with a cloud-based Multi-Layer Radio Environment Map (ML-REM) that builds upon the database-enabled side information techniques pioneered for the 3.5 GHz band. Over-the-air data obtained through propagation measurements will be used to construct the ML-REM. The research will be tested experimentally on a joint SDN and software defined radio (SDR) testbed, with the experimental results being integrated into theoretical models for continuous improvement and testing.

por.por_cntn:
The demand for wireless broadband is growing across the world. Access to high-capacity wireless communication is critical to the operation of any modern society. The increasing demand for spectrum requires novel solutions, capable of addressing the high user-density and mobility of future wireless services. This project examined the design and analysis of wireless communications systems operating in the millimeter-wave bands, to enable efficient and seamless network operation in highly-dynamic environments characterized by high density and mobility of wireless devices. This project addressed the theoretical and experimental issues that are impeding the deployment of millimeter-wave wireless broadband systems, by focusing on the interplay between network-level optimization and physical layer communication, channel sounding, and control.

The project led to advances in the modeling and characterization of site-specific propagation environments, including suburban and rural areas. Propagation measurements were carried out at 28GHz using a millimeter-wave front end interfaced with a Universal Software Radio Peripheral (USRP) software-defined radio and a cloud computing cluster. A proof-of-concept of a fully-automated system for learning site-specific propagation features was developed, and experimental campaigns were carried out in sub-urban and forest environments in Boulder, CO, and the USNA campus in Annapolis, MD. One of the successes of the project was to develop a fully autonomous robotic antenna tracking platform for the mechanical beam-steering of highly directional fixed-beam horn antennas, designed using commercial off-the-shelf components. This system was successfully tested and demonstrated on the NSF POWDER testbed in Salt Lake City, UT.

One of the goals of the project was to develop optimization algorithms to enable beam alignment and high spectral efficiency in highly mobile propagation environments operating with directional beams. Among the successes of the project include novel algorithms based on Markov decision theory, multi-armed bandits, and machine learning to optimize the procedures of beam-training and beam-tracking, and to optimize the trade-off between the overhead of beam-training and data transmission. This study led to a design that learns local properties of the propagation environment from on-the-field measurements, and adaptively optimizes the beam-training and data transmission processes to maximize the spectral efficiency of the system. This design will be especially critical to meet the capacity, delay, and reliability requirements of future vehicular networks.

Another success of the project was the design of novel beamforming and feedback adaptive communication techniques, that leverage feedback to improve the beam alignment procedure.  By posing the alignment problem as a questioning strategy, this study developed both adaptive (closed-loop) and non-adaptive (open-loop) channel sounding techniques that are robust to erroneous feedback from the receiver.

Another successful outcome includes the development of novel learning and adaptation strategies to improve spectrum usage in multi-user systems. The proposed solution learns frequency and temporal occupancy patterns, and efficiently detects available spectrum opportunities, leading to improved spectrum utilization and minimal interference to ongoing transmissions. Finally, another major goal of the project was to develop novel signal processing techniques to enhance massive MIMO channel estimation at millimeter-wave frequencies. One major accomplishment of the project was to develop novel techniques based on tensor completion and compression sensing that leverage spatial correlations of the propagation paths to enable fast position-aided beam-alignment with small training overhead.

The broader impacts included the mentoring and education of students in the combination of cross-layer approaches to 5G and beyond wireless systems. This ranged from measurement and testbed research up to higher layers. The project resulted in several journal and conference paper publications. Several graduated Ph.D. students incorporated the research into their Ph.D. thesis. The project led to new graduate-level courses on modern digital and wireless communications, and learning-based sequential decision making under uncertainty. The project was also aligned with an undergraduate research team. The research developed will likely contribute to the success of 5G and will benefit society through the plethora of applications that 5G promises, such as the Internet of Things to improve automation of transportation systems and home management. It will enable practical schemes to support the increase in demand for mobile high throughput services such as virtual reality; lower the cost of deployment of communication systems, and thus provide benefits to rural or underdeveloped areas with limited access to the internet.
